node.contents: @Mikhail this is just a very minimal example of our use case. We launch some RecursiveActions inside the callable which get invoked on ForkJoinTask.getPool()

node.contents: BTW, why are you using FJP for this case?

node.contents: I just noticed the following phenomena when cancelling a Future returned by ForkJoinPool. Given the following example code:

astNode.text: I just noticed the following phenomena when cancelling a Future returned by ForkJoinPool. Given the following example code:

elements.contents: ForkJoinPool pool = new ForkJoinPool(); Future<?> fut = pool.submit(new Callable<Void>() { @Override public Void call() throws Exception { while (true) { if (Thread.currentThread().isInterrupted()) { // <-- never true System.out.println("interrupted"); throw new InterruptedException(); } } } }); Thread.sleep(1000); System.out.println("cancel"); fut.cancel(true);

comments.text: // <-- never true System.out.println("interrupted"); throw new InterruptedException(); } } } }); Thread.sleep(1000); System.out.println("cancel"); fut.cancel(true);

node.contents: The program never prints interrupted. The docs of ForkJoinTask#cancel(boolean) say:

astNode.text: The program never prints interrupted. The docs of ForkJoinTask#cancel(boolean) say:

node.contents: mayInterruptIfRunning - this value has no effect in the default implementation because interrupts are not used to control cancellation.

astNode.text: mayInterruptIfRunning - this value has no effect in the default implementation because interrupts are not used to control cancellation.

node.contents: If ForkJoinTasks ignore interrupts, how else are you supposed to check for cancellation inside Callables submitted to a ForkJoinPool?

astNode.text: If ForkJoinTasks ignore interrupts, how else are you supposed to check for cancellation inside Callables submitted to a ForkJoinPool?

node.contents: Thanks Mikhail for your investigation. Looks like there is no way to check for cancellation from within a Callable. I'll need to submit a ForkJoinTask and call isCancelled() on that, which sucks because you always need to pass a around the reference to ForkJoinTask to check for cancellation

astNode.text: Thanks Mikhail for your investigation. Looks like there is no way to check for cancellation from within a Callable. I'll need to submit a ForkJoinTask and call isCancelled() on that, which sucks because you always need to pass a around the reference to ForkJoinTask to check for cancellation

node.contents: This happens because Future<?> is a ForkJoinTask.AdaptedCallable which extends ForkJoinTask, whose cancel method is:

astNode.text: This happens because Future<?> is a ForkJoinTask.AdaptedCallable which extends ForkJoinTask, whose cancel method is:

elements.contents: public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning) { return setCompletion(CANCELLED) == CANCELLED; } private int setCompletion(int completion) { for (int s;;) { if ((s = status) < 0) return s; if (UNSAFE.compareAndSwapInt(this, statusOffset, s, completion)) { if (s != 0) synchronized (this) { notifyAll(); } return completion; } } }

units.rawText: public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning) { return setCompletion(CANCELLED) == CANCELLED; } private int setCompletion(int completion) { for (int s;;) { if ((s = status) < 0) return s; if (UNSAFE.compareAndSwapInt(this, statusOffset, s, completion)) { if (s != 0) synchronized (this) { notifyAll(); } return completion; } } }

node.contents: It does not do any interruptions, it just sets status. I suppose this happens becouse ForkJoinPools's Futures might have a very complicated tree structure, and it is unclear in which order to cancel them.

astNode.text: It does not do any interruptions, it just sets status. I suppose this happens becouse ForkJoinPools's Futures might have a very complicated tree structure, and it is unclear in which order to cancel them.
